thread.title: 'It feels good:' North West River getting restaurant after years without
thread.title_full: 'It feels good:' North West River getting restaurant after years without

author: cbc
title: 'It feels good:' North West River getting restaurant after years without
text:
It isn't easy to find a place to eat if you're in North West River, Labrador and it hasn't been for quite some time.
In fact, the community hasn't had a sit-down-take-out restaurant, for about a decade - but that's about to change.
Heather's Place is getting ready to open its doors.
"A dream come true," Heather Keats told the CBC. "I'm bouncin' right now!"
Heather Keats managed a bar/restaurant in Happy Valley-Goose Bay for 13 years. She says it's a dream come true to have her own place. (Jacob Barker/CBC)
Keats managed Maxwell-Bentley's, a bar/restaurant in Happy Valley-Goose Bay for 13 years and has always wanted a restaurant of her own.
"Hot roast beef sandwiches, hot turkeys, burgers, fries, poutines, salads..." Keats said when asked what kind of food the restaurant will serve. "Pretty much everything under the sun."
A local bed and breakfast does offer guests hot meals and a cafe was set up to serve fresh food one summer, but the town has lacked a permanent establishment for a long time.
The cast and crew of "Last Stop Garage" were served the first meal at Heather's Place recently. Baikie says it will open to the public in the coming weeks. (Jacob Barker/CBC)
"North West River always had a restaurant," Leander Baikie, with CRB Automotive said. "But there hasn't been one open in the community for the last 8-10 years."
The garage bought the building right behind its shop and are leasing it to Keats and another cook to run.
Last Stop Garage: North West River gets reality TV show "We said, 'Right now we have it within our power to create a restaurant and put it back in the community,' which is something everyone wants," Baikie said. "Sometimes you go to Goose Bay and the restaurant's filled with North West River, Sheshatshiu people."
Welcoming tool The business bought the building about 16 months ago and did a full renovation. They served their first meal recently to a crew in town filming a reality series at CRB.
They hope to have it open to the public in the coming weeks.
Leander Baikie says the community hasn't had a restaurant in the past 8-10 years. (Jacob Barker/CBC)
Baikie says the business will be a good welcoming tool for tourists and visitors showing up "at the end of the open road... the farthest place in northeastern North America you can drive in an automobile."
"It feels good. It feels really, really good," he said. "It's about damn time."
